body: Travis CI Build Failure is totally unrelated to this change, let's discuss that in [FINERACT-779](https://jira.apache.org/jira/browse/FINERACT-779) ...
This, ideally (to avoid doing required adjustment work twice) requires #607 as a pre-requisite, first.

> org.apache.fineract.integrationtests.HookIntegrationTest

Huh, this test actuallly PASSES locally if I try it out (from this branch) like this:

    ./gradlew integrationTest --tests org.apache.fineract.integrationtests.HookIntegrationTest

So this probably is "just" a flaky test, unrelated to this PR; I've opened [FINERACT-780](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FINERACT-780).

I've manually restarted a Travis CI build for this PR, let's see if it's better on another run.

> I don't really understand
> 
> ```
> org.apache.fineract.integrationtests.HookIntegrationTest > shouldSendOfficeCreationNotification FAILED
>     java.lang.AssertionError at HookIntegrationTest.java:79
> ```
> 
> My changes shouldn't really affect this.



> I reran the tests by closing & reopening the PR.
> This time it passed successfully.

==> https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FINERACT-780
Voil√†, build passed - ready for review & merge... @conradsp @awasum @vishwasbabu - tx!

> Travis CI Build Failure is totally unrelated to this change, let's discuss that in [FINERACT-779](https://jira.apache.org/jira/browse/FINERACT-779) ...

No, it actually was due to this change, see details in [FINERACT-779](https://jira.apache.org/jira/browse/FINERACT-779); I've now amended this PR with a change to the logging configuration which should hopefully make this PR pass the Travis build.

@vorburger - One question - I am not sure why we still need to compile the bval bundle if it is not used anywhere in the codebase anymore. Otherwise, looks good - I'll build locally and run integration tests as well and merge if it all passes.
Integration tests all passing locally.

> @vorburger - One question - I am not sure why we still need to compile the bval bundle if it is not used anywhere in the codebase anymore.

I learnt (only AFTER our related discussion over in #606 / #617) that we actually *DO* use Apache BVal, as our javax.validation implementation of choice. The point of #606 / #617 remains valid - we should not have any direct dependencies in code to BVal (only to the javax.validation API), but we do need it at runtime. [FINERACT-777](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FINERACT-777) will make this clearer.

Without the Apache BVal dependency, Spring Boot start-up fails, complaining that there is no implementation for the javax.validation API available on the classpath.

With this PR, that now becomes a lot more explicit than this used to be (previously it was hidden away inside the openjpa-all fat √ºber JAR, which can be confusing). I guess in theory we chould now even experiment with swapping it out against an alternative implementation (although I have no plans to do so).

> Integration tests all passing locally.

as well as on Travis CI (just sayin' this to make sure that you are are that when on a PR there is a green "All checks have passed: 1 successful check", as on this one here, just below of this comment, this actually 'proves' that integration tests passed, on Travis).
Thanks @vorburger. I ran integration tests locally again, given some of the earlier comments about a bit of flakiness. Will merge now.
@conradsp what do you think?  @lingocoder FYI
@conradsp would you perhaps like to review/test/merge this?

The last commit I just added to this PR will, hopefully, fix the problem above; see last comment in [FINERACT-700](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FINERACT-700) for some details of what happened and how I fixed it. - Travis is currently running, and I'm going to bed now; cross fingers it will pass... :smiley:

I recommend isolating small PRs and not mixing this effort (FINERACT-777) together with e.g. Java 11 or Spring upgrades (all of which we would certainly very much welcome your help with as well, in separate PRs!)

OK if I get back in touch when my availability changes?

Could you answer a question for me in the meantime though, please? What would you give as the reason for  [*that Gradle wrapper upgrade task taking five months from start to finish*](http://bit.ly/525Feb19)? 

By contrast, Gradle itself has had [*six releases within that same amount of time*](http://bit.ly/GrdlRles).
Yes, this looks good. Merging.

> rebase this on top of that, and only then merge this?

done, and it passes. @awasum @conradsp @vishwasbabu would you like to merge this?

FTR: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/OPENJPA-2730 has what we need OpenJPA v2.4.3. This alone doesn't quite do the trick for https://github.com/apache/fineract/pull/609, see https://github.com/radcortez/openjpa-gradle-plugin/issues/8 for why. IMHO it would still make sense to merge this already right now though; I'll deal with the follow-up in #609.

Hi @awasum I opened this pull request as a follow up for [Pull Request 465 ](https://github.com/apache/fineract/pull/465). You may get a bigger idea about this if you check that pull request. If you want a more detailed I may try to update it.

The general idea for the Rates Module is that rate amounts can be associated to a description and later be used to set the nominal interest rate used to create a loan.

For our business the nominal interest rate, is calculated by adding multiple rate previously defined, for example: let's say I have a specific rate for widowed people of 8%, a specific rate for college students of  7 % and a general rate for all of our clients of 6 % . When a widowed person comes and asks for a loan I may have choose the widowed rate and general rate to get the rate of  14%. These rates also help us restrict the interest amount that can be set when creating a new loan account beyond the min and max values.

This changes are mostly reflected in the Mifos UI because we didn't wanted to change a lot of how Fineract works actually. However the amount of files changed and added here may be overwhelming for some but all previous reviews have improved the idea we had initially about this module.

@angelboxes sorry I forgot if you are a committer? If yes, please do go ahead and merge PRs, such as this, and others, which LGTY... you don't have to wait e.g. for me; on the contrary, I very much hope for more active other committers who review and merge.

Hm, OK but between "Integration test cases fail when run on the 1st of a month" (FINERACT-722) and "Travis is just completely broken right now" (FINERACT-788) may be the former is the lesser of two evils? :smiling_imp: Or is there another better quick fix here that anyone can think of?

I guess we could keep (just) the `export TZ=Asia/Kolkata` - would that be better?

> Hm, OK but between "Integration test cases fail when run on the 1st of a month" (FINERACT-722) and "Travis is just completely broken right now" (FINERACT-788) may be the former is the lesser of two evils? üòà Or is there another better quick fix here that anyone can think of?
> 
> I guess we could keep (just) the `export TZ=Asia/Kolkata` - would that be better?

Yes of course :) . We could also hard-code the date to "21 August 2019 01:02:03" and hope FINERACT-722 is fixed within the next 5 months !

> > I guess we could keep (just) the `export TZ=Asia/Kolkata` - would that be better?

In a 2nd commit to this PR, I've just reverted that removal, so we keep `TZ` but rm `date`.

> We could also hard-code the date to "21 August 2019 01:02:03" 

Nah, that just postpones the problem - the same issue will just re-occur when services.gradle.org renews their cert the next time around... I really think we should avoid hard-coding a fixed time here (because of this problem).

> and hope FINERACT-722 is fixed within the next 5 months !

hope dies last! :smile_cat: 

I'll self merge this in 48h, unless someone else does before or suggests a better solution.

Adding Authentication and common params for swagger documentation to each and every endpoint(API's ) is unnecessary and is not a good coding standard.
It will increase redundant code for auth to every API's, which can be done by sharing a common resource to all the API's

In the review of removing Auth params from every API in your commit: 
https://github.com/kangbreder/fineract/commit/7418ac403e4e145c86dd826086a2799dd5c4bf7c#commitcomment-34794554

Here are some reference links which you can refer to remove those params!
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/47627469/swagger2-too-many-the-same-annotations
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39853217/swagger-how-to-combine-shared-information-from-different-apis

Okay. I will consider that and let you know.
